newsitem.title: INDIA: India's SEBI reduces new issue lots to 200 shares.
newsitem.headline: India's SEBI reduces new issue lots to 200 shares.

text.p: The Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) said on Tuesday its board decided to reduce the minimum application lots for primary issues to 200 shares from 500 shares.
The market regulator said it will no longer scrutinise new issue offer documents.
SEBI had been vetting offer documents only of ventures in which financial institutions or banks had a 10 percent stake and the projects were appraised by them.
It had earlier given up vetting of rights and debt issues by firms with a three-year track record of dividend payments.
The market watchdog said it also decided to allow firms list their debt issues on stock exchanges before their shares are listed.
The SEBI board decided to scrap the 1.0 billion rupee minimum issue size for companies to raise funds through the book building process.
It said issues of all sizes can opt for the book building route to raise cash.
SEBI said it also relaxed rules and allowed promoters to bring in their contribution in phases for large infrastructure projects where such contribution exceeded one billion rupees.
Earlier, the relaxation was only available to promoters whose firms had a five-year track record of consistent profits and where the premiums on the stock offer did not exceed its face value.
